_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Dow Victoria Site of The Dow Chemical Company is committed to operating all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We have implemented a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment. These programs include both internal Responsible Care requirements and governmental requirements, such as the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION

The Dow Victoria Site consists of 38 acres, located approximately 9 miles south of the city of Victoria, in a rural setting south of SH 185.  The plant functions as a "tenant" on the larger INVISTA Victoria Plant site.

The plant consists of one manufacturing process producing Ethylene Copolymers (low-density Polyethylene resins).  In the production of these products, the following regulated substances are used:  
RMP Toxic Chemical - Vinyl Acetate
RMP Flammable Chemicals - Ethylene, Propane, and Propylene

WORST-CASE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario for a toxic chemical is a release of 185,000 lbs. of Vinyl Acetate from a railcar.   This release has an off-site impact, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.  No mitigation was assumed for the analysis, but depending on the location of the railcar, the following mitigations could be in place to mitigate the consequences of the event:
1) Operator attendance during loading/unloading to determine the condition of railcars and observe leaks.  Cameras are also available for monitoring.
2)  Preventive maintenance program on the railcars and loading/unloading facilities.
3)  Combustible Gas Detectors to detect flammable vapors and alert personnel.


WORST-CASE FLAMMABLE RELEASE

SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario for a flammable chemical is a 86,300 lb. release of Propane from the Propane Storage Tank.  This release, if ignited, would have an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.  The ignition of this release is unlikely because the tank is located in a remote location versus normal ignition sources.  No mitigation was assumed for the analysis, but the following mitigations are in place to mitigate the consequences of the event: 
1) Surveillance: Personnel make rounds to determine the condition of equipment and observe leaks.  Cameras are also available for surveillance.
2) Tank pressure and level are alarmed and are monitored remotely via DCS.


ALTERNATIVE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS

Vinyl acetate monomer (VA) - A leak from the Vinyl Acetate storage tank with mitigation from secondary containment was assumed.  Other mitigation includes Combustible Gas Detectors to detect flammable vapors and alert personnel.  This release has an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.

ALTERNATIVE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO

Propane - A BLEVE from the Propane Tank was assumed.  This release has an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.  The ignition of this release is unlikely because the tank is located in a remote location versus normal ignition sources.  No mitigation was assumed for the analysis, but the following mitigations are in place to mitigate the consequences of the event: 
1) Surveillance: Personnel make rounds to determine the condition of equipment and observe leaks.  Cameras are also available for surveillance. 
2) Pressure and level are alarmed and are monitored remotely via DCS.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Dow Victoria Site

follows the requirements of corporate standards for Process Safety Management.  These standards include the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.

Our Safety Programs include:

Designing for Safety ...
   - A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.
   - Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.
   - Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.
   - Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.
   - Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.

Maintaining our Plant ...
   - Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.
   - Contractors are trained and qualified.
   - A work permit system controls hazards.

Operating Safety ...
   - Operators are trained and job qualified.
   - Technical resources are available and utilized as required.
   - Operators follow approved procedures.

Auditing our Operations ...
   - Routine safety inspections are conducted.
   - Corporate, independent and government audits and reviews are conducted.
   - Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.
   - Safety critical equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.
   - Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment.
   - Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.
   - Incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.

          SAFETY IS A JOB REQUIREMENT FOR ALL EMPLOYEES AND CONTRACTORS!

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has resulted from a release of any of the regulated chemicals (Vinyl Acetate, Ethylene, Propane, or Propylene) in the pa

st five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to any releases of the regulated chemicals.  The program can be summarized as follows:

*Emergency Contacts...
   -Incident Command can be contacted during emergencies at 361-553-2423. 

*  Training and Preparation ...
   - Plant personnel receive emergency response training.
   - Plant emergency responders are trained.
   - Emergency response plans are current.
   - Plant participates in emergency drills.
   - Critiques are held on drills and actual events.
   - Plant is a member of the Victoria Local Emergency Planning Committee.

*  If a Major Release Occurs ...
   - Emergency alarm is sounded.
   - Plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.
   - Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.
   - Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

On-going programs, such as process hazard analysis reevaluations, continually aim to improve process safety.  The following is a list of specific improvements that we are planning to implement to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases: 1) Complete the Layers of Protection Analysis and ensure the necessary layers are in place.  2)  Conduct periodic process hazard analyses and implement resulting recommendations for improvements to safety equipment and procedures.  3) Conduct New Leader Reviews so that newly assigned production leaders have all of the process safety and reactive chemicals information necessary for their new jobs.  4) All new projects are designed around principles of inherent safety so that process safety is integrated directly into the design.  5) Changes to new or revised systems seek to minimize the quantities of hazardous materials
